hackathon-description-text: Teams created data-driven applications to increase public engagement and aid in Chesapeake Bay restoration at the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center in Edgewater, MD.

hackathon-judges.judge-role: President, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science
Deputy Secretary, Maryland Department of the Environment
Executive Program Officer, Library of Congress
Deputy Director, Smithsonian Environmental Research Center

hackathon-eligibility: Programmers, scientists, and other "civic hackers" were all invited. We encouraged individuals to team-up. Teams could have an unlimited number of members. If individuals didn't already have a team, we helped them find one at the event.
hackathon-requirements: Submissions were for data-driven applications to help the Chesapeake Bay. Submissions could range from working software prototypes to polished mockup presentations. Refer to the judging criteria for how submissions were judged.
hackathon-rules: Refer to the guidelines and instructions on the Home page.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Up to 4 teams will be awarded $1000 per team.  Team finalists will compete for the "Governor's Cup."
Grand prize awarded to best team finalist on August 27

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=Smithsonian Environmental Research Center, 647 Contees Wharf Road, Edgewater, MD 21037, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How much the idea will help the Chesapeake Bay
Originality and creativity of the idea and how the data is used
Whether it is realistic to implement and sustain the idea

hackathon-location-address: Smithsonian Environmental Research Center, 647 Contees Wharf Road, Edgewater, MD 21037, USA
hackathon-description-header: Create data-driven applications to help the Chesapeake Bay
